name: AI Safety quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Help ensure advanced AI systems don’t cause catastrophic harm, by improving how we build/evaluate/govern/deploy powerful AI (technical safety + governance/policy).
roleShapes: Technical research (alignment, interpretability, evals, robustness)
Research engineering (tools, eval pipelines, infra for safety)
Governance / policy / strategy
Security / preparedness / model risk
Ops / programs / field-building
Communications / writing
fitSignals: Motivated by high-stakes downside risk + can tolerate uncertainty/debate
Drawn to either: technical challenge, governance complexity, or enabling infrastructure/community
OK with long feedback loops (or choose Experiment C to make it concrete fast)

handsOn.title: Hands-on trial
handsOn.description: Hands-on trial SPAR — a part-time remote program explicitly structured around impactful research projects with mentors in AI safety/policy. Optional alt (bigger commitment): MATS (intensive mentored research program)…

name: Animal × AI quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Use AI to reduce animal suffering (farmed and wild) by improving how we measure welfare, prevent harms, target advocacy, and design interventions — while also being careful about ways AI deployment can accidentally increase suffering (e.g., scale effects, mismeasurement, perverse incentives). (Animal Charity Evaluators)
roleShapes: Applied ML for wild animal welfare: human–wildlife conflict mitigation, monitoring welfare indicators (e.g., vocalizations), detection/early warning systems. (Rethink Priorities)
AI in farmed animal systems: how AI in agriculture/aquaculture changes welfare (sometimes better, sometimes worse), plus interventions to steer it. (Rethink Priorities)
AI for animal advocacy orgs: LLM-enabled research workflows, message testing, supporter comms, grantwriting support, ops automation (done carefully). (Faunalytics)
Research & strategy at think tanks (what AI applications are promising, where are risks/unknowns). (Rethink Priorities)
Programs / community / hackathons for building tools and pipelines for animal protection. (Electric Sheep)
fitSignals: You like concrete technical leverage (data/ML) and you’re motivated by animals.
You’re comfortable with “applied + messy” domains (datasets, field conditions, imperfect metrics).
You can hold a balanced stance: “AI can help” and “AI can harm if used carelessly.” (Animal Charity Evaluators)

name: Animal Welfare quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Reduce large-scale animal suffering — especially in areas where many animals are affected (e.g., factory farming), by changing policies, corporate practices, consumer behavior, and the systems that determine how animals are treated. 80,000 Hours+1
roleShapes: Campaigns & corporate outreach (commitments, implementation, accountability)
Policy / legal / government relations
Research & analysis (what works, which tactics, which species/interventions)
Communications / storytelling / movement building
Operations / management / fundraising (often a major bottleneck)
Science/alt-protein/food systems (depending on the person)
Animal x AI – different cause area
fitSignals: Strong “moral pull” toward animals + willingness to engage practical levers (institutions, corporations, policy)
Comfort with advocacy, persuasion, and coordination (many roles are people-facing)
Or: strong “evidence-minded” instinct (measurement, research, strategy) Faunalytics+1

name: Biosecurity / Pandemic preparedness quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Reduce catastrophic biological risks (natural outbreaks and engineered pathogens) by improving prevention, detection, response, and policy—so society is far less vulnerable to extreme pandemics. 80,000 Hours+1
roleShapes: Public health security / policy / strategy
Technical work (biosurveillance, diagnostics, PPE/engineering controls, forecasting)
Research & analysis (risk assessment, program evaluation, modeling)
Ops/programs (running initiatives, coordination, funding ops)
AI-bio risk work (when relevant) 80,000 Hours
fitSignals: Motivated by preparedness + systems thinking (institutions, incentives, coordination)
Comfortable with policy/bureaucracy and/or technical public health work
Often benefits from “make it concrete” steps (projects, job-board scan), because the space can feel abstract

name: Climate quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Rapidly reduce greenhouse gas emissions (and support adaptation where it’s most valuable) by pushing on the highest-leverage bottlenecks: policy, clean energy deployment, targeted innovation, and (in some cases) carbon removal. Both 80,000 Hours and Probably Good emphasize that career choice tends to matter more than personal footprint, and that some climate actions are much more effective than others. 80,000 Hours+1
roleShapes: A useful “menu” (not a checklist):
Policy / government / regulation (often very leveraged; hard to attribute impact, but can be huge). Probably Good+1
Climate-focused engineering / tech (clean power, industrial decarbonization, storage, etc.). Probably Good+1
Research (climate science, modelling, carbon removal R&D, or “what actually works” analysis). 80,000 Hours+1
Advocacy / communications (especially around “neglected-but-effective” interventions). 80,000 Hours+1
Climate finance / impact investing (moving large sums can matter; also easy to do “busy work,” so select carefully). Probably Good+1
Community / field-building (helping others enter or coordinate effectively). Work on Climate+1
fitSignals: You’re willing to be a bit strategic (choosing which slice of climate to push on, not just “anything climate”). Probably Good+1
You can tolerate imperfect feedback loops (policy + systems change can be slow and hard to measure). Probably Good+1
You like high-leverage work: “one decision / one institution → very large downstream effects.”

name: Global Health & Development quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: Reduce large-scale suffering and premature death by scaling interventions that are cheap, evidence-backed, and logistically feasible (e.g., malaria prevention/treatment, vaccinations, nutrition). (80,000 Hours)
roleShapes: Program implementation & field ops (distribution, logistics, monitoring)
Research & evaluation (development econ, epidemiology, cost-effectiveness, RCTs)
Grantmaking / philanthropy (moving money well; vetting)
Policy and government implementation (health systems, procurement, public finance)
Entrepreneurship / founding new orgs (esp. “evidence-to-scale” nonprofits) (80,000 Hours)
fitSignals: You’re motivated by measurable impact and are OK with “unsexy” operational realities (supply chains, compliance, systems)
You like working with messy real-world constraints and still making steady progress
You enjoy evidence and tradeoffs (not only “what’s morally urgent” but also “what works”) (80,000 Hours)
